steps.title: Pour 2 to 3 large tablespoons of turpentine into a small (tumbler sized) glass.
steps.content: Pour 2 to 3 large tablespoons of turpentine into a small (tumbler sized) glass.

steps.title: Place the matches, (head down) into the turpentine and allow the matches to soak for 5 minutes.
steps.content: Place the matches, (head down) into the turpentine and allow the matches to soak for 5 minutes. During that time the turpentine will soak into the head as well as the stem. All the water will be driven off by the turpentine.

steps.title: Remove the matches and spread them out to dry out on a sheet of newspaper.
steps.content: Remove the matches and spread them out to dry out on a sheet of newspaper. Generally, 20 minutes for excess turpentine to evaporate is recommended. Matches treated in this way remain waterproof for several months or longer.

steps.title: Dip the head end of the match into clear nail polish far enough to cover at least an eighth of an inch (3 millimeters) of the stick below the head.
steps.content: Dip the head end of the match into clear nail polish far enough to cover at least an eighth of an inch (3 millimeters) of the stick below the head.

steps.title: Hold the match for a few seconds to allow the polish to dry and then place the match on a table or counter so that the head is suspended off the edge of the surface.
steps.content: Hold the match for a few seconds to allow the polish to dry and then place the match on a table or counter so that the head is suspended off the edge of the surface.

steps.title: Place a sheet of newsprint below to catch anything that may drip off.
steps.content: Place a sheet of newsprint below to catch anything that may drip off.

steps.title: Light a candle and let it burn down until you have a good amount of liquid wax (about a half of an inch or 1 centimeter).
steps.content: Light a candle and let it burn down until you have a good amount of liquid wax (about a half of an inch or 1 centimeter). [1] X Research source

steps.title: Dip the head end of the match into the wax far enough to cover at least an eighth of an inch (3 millimeters) of the stick below the head.
steps.content: Dip the head end of the match into the wax far enough to cover at least an eighth of an inch (3 millimeters) of the stick below the head.

steps.title: Hold the match for a few seconds to allow the wax to harden slightly and then place the match on a table or counter so that the head is suspended off the edge of the surface.
steps.content: Hold the match for a few seconds to allow the wax to harden slightly and then place the match on a table or counter so that the head is suspended off the edge of the surface. [2] X Research source

steps.title: When the wax has cooled, but not completely hardened, pinch the end of the wax coating (towards the stick), forming a tight seal.
steps.content: When the wax has cooled, but not completely hardened, pinch the end of the wax coating (towards the stick), forming a tight seal.

steps.title: Melt enough paraffin wax in a double boiler to be able to coat with wax about a half of an inch (1 centimeter) deep.
steps.content: Melt enough paraffin wax in a double boiler to be able to coat with wax about a half of an inch (1 centimeter) deep. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Wrap some twine or jute string around several matches from the bottom, to just below the wax quickly.
steps.content: Wrap some twine or jute string around several matches from the bottom, to just below the wax quickly. This makes a torch that can burn for 10 or more minutes.
